awd_titl_txt: CC* CIRA: Shared Arkansas Research Plan for Community Cyber Infrastructure (SHARP CCI)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

SHARP CCI creates a statewide research cyber infrastructure (RCI) Plan for Arkansas that is focused on the eight degree granting institutions performing science and engineering research. Participating institutions include: Arkansas State University (ASU); Southern Arkansas University (SAU); University of Arkansas (UA) Fayetteville (UAF); UA Division of Agriculture (UADA); UA Little Rock (UALR); UA Medical Sciences (UAMS); UA Pine Bluff (UAPB); and University of Central Arkansas (UCA). Each school has a growing demand for federated access to high-speed resources, managed services and technical training; however, a coordinated plan for providing these capabilities does not currently exist. Most schools in Arkansas lack the connectivity, budget and staffing to fully utilize these statewide resources, and each school is unique in technical capability and expertise. SHARP CCI assembles the senior administrators and research leaders at each school to document the environments, capabilities, technology needs and resource gaps and create an equitable RCI Plan to inform decision makers in the state. This plan will also provide a necessary resource for each school to apply for additional NSF support through solicitations that expand school infrastructure and training capabilities.

A statewide RCI Plan is requisite for organizing and expanding research collaborations and it fosters an economy-of-scale for building compliant facilities and systems and establishing a managed service environment for schools with limited resources. SHARP CCI includes establishing a comprehensive data science training program, Arkansas Cyber Team (ACT), to provide engineers, educators, researchers and students access to technical expertise in a broad range of scientific domains. The project team includes Arkansas Research and Education Optical Network, Great Plains Network, Open Science Grid and NSF’s Engagement and Performance Operations Center to provide engineering and training expertise, managed service experience and help in implementing a statewide RCI Plan for Arkansas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The rapid growth and diversification of research computing and data (RCD) across virtually all science. engineering, and humanities disciplines poses significant challenges to academic institutions in Arkansas and across the United States. They must effectively assess and plan for growth in capability while maintaining the reseasrch cyberinfrasturucture that is required to keep pace with the growing needs of researchers. The level at which a school supports researchers has consequential impacts on recruiting new faculty and students who come with high expectations of cyberinfrastructure support and capacity, and in the winning of new grants which require state-of-the-art research computing infrastructure and levels of support. These universities need to assess their support capabilities in comparison to peers and take action to fill the gaps.

SHARP was designed to address this issue across eight instutions in Arkansas, including one R1 Universty and a resesarch-active community college, and to coordinate a collective response. The Research Computing and Data Capabilities Model survey was desigined for institutions to evaluate their current standing in a variety of RCD services and capabilities for supporting research and to.leverage a shared vocabulary to describe RCD support. The Model supports a range of stakeholders and provides structured input to guide strategic planning and enable benchmarking relative to peer institutions.

Using organziational structures and meetings managed by the state's Track 1 DART project, two RCD CM assessments, the full survey and another significantly abridged version developed by the SHARP team amd intended to engage a larger audience, were completed at all eight institutions and theresults indicate that while these Arkansas universties and colleges have a generally positive feeling toward RCD (with shared resources provided through the Arkansas Research Platform), the active use of these resources is still limited by lack of training and cyberinfrastructure preparation at client institutions. SHARP addressed these shortcomings by collecting, creating, and sharing tools and refrence documents that guide universities and colledges in Arkansas to develop CI Plans that help provide robust, safe, and efficient access the Arkansas Research Platform. It also provided support for the develpoment of extensive on-site training at eight institutions across Arkansas. The network of IT administrators, academic adminstrators, faculty, and staff remains an active element of CI discussions with the Arkansas EPSCoR jurisdiction.
